{{Philosophy-sidebar}}
 
{{Philosophy-sidebar}}
    −
'''Ethics''' (also known as '''moral philosophy''') is a branch of [[philosophy]] which seeks to address questions about [[morality]], such as what the fundamental [[semantic]], [[ontological]], and [[epistemic]] nature of ethics or morality is ([[meta-ethics]]), how moral values should be determined ([[normative ethics]]), how a moral outcome can be achieved in specific situations ([[applied ethics]]), how moral capacity or moral agency develops and what its nature is ([[moral psychology]]), and what moral values people actually abide by ([[descriptive ethics]]).Ethics also means belonging to a particular racial group within a large set or group of people.
+
'''Ethics''' (also known as '''moral philosophy''') is a branch of [[philosophy]] which seeks to address questions about [[morality]], such as what the fundamental [[semantic]], [[ontological]], and [[epistemic]] nature of ethics or morality is ([[meta-ethics]]), how moral values should be determined ([[normative ethics]]), how a moral outcome can be achieved in specific situations ([[applied ethics]]), how moral capacity or moral agency develops and what its nature is ([[moral psychology]]), and what moral values people actually abide by ([[descriptive ethics]]).
